field_edited_text.value:
Comparison of the Harbor Route with the Northern Route

Ty oyL



L



The above figures give no indication of housing quality. The demo-
lition of one good building is obviously a wholly different matter from
the demolition of a slum building. Furthermore a count of residential
properties fails to indicate the number of dwellings to be torn down. Some
residential properties may contain more than one dwelling (one on the
Northern Route contains approximately 150) and some dwellings are
located in buildings not classified as residential structures. To cover both
points Table 3 presents a tabulation of dwellings along each route broken
down by sections and by estimated quality. The results are shown
graphically in Sheet 35. Good dwellings are those built since 1950 or
which appear obviously good from exterior inspection. Poor dwellings are
those listed as dilapidated or lacking private baths in the 1950 U. S. Hous-
ing Census. Fair dwellings are all others. These criteria for quality are
admittedly rough, but since the same criteria were applied against both
routes the comparisons are believed to be reasonably valid.

An inspection of Table 3 indicates that the Harbor Route scores
better on all counts. Omitting the sections which are common, total
dwellings are only 1,198 for the Harbor Route as against 3,593 for the
Northern Route. On the Northern Route 21.99% of the dwellings rate as
good; the corresponding figure for the Harbor Route is zero. 70.8% of the
dwellings on the Harbor Route are poor; only 24.99% are so classified on
the Northern Route.

Effect on Assessed Valuations

Any public improvement involving the acquisition of property ad-
versely effects the tax rolls. The amount of assessed valuations of the
property to be taken for the two alternative expressway routes is therefore
a matter of concern.
